column5: In 1779, after a campaign against the Indians, General Sullivan ordered his troops to kill and leave behind superfluous horses near what is now known as Horseheads, New York, resulting in heaps of horse skulls discovered by later settlers. These settlers named their village Horseheads in reference to these skull monuments, honoring a historic moment in the area's past.
To avoid murder; but keep their smuggling secret - villains cut out the tongue of the unfortunate woman who once lived on this lane.
Dramatic mountain pass called 'Troll’s Path'; local legends of trolls abound.
Name said to come from a fencing school
Oldest continuously inhabited residential street in the US; site of many local ghost stories.
Manx superstition says greet the fairies when crossing or risk bad luck.
Site of fierce Civil War fighting at Antietam; central to local ghost stories.
Nods to Salem's infamous 17th-century witch trials and enduring witch lore.
A scenic but precarious route in Utah; name evokes danger and local frontier tales.
Famously associated with Washington Irving’s 'The Legend of Sleepy Hollow.'
Named for a 17th-century figure rumored to be a witch; local folklore persists.
'Fairies' Bay'; local lore claims fairies once protected the coastline.
‘Teufel’ = devil in German; associated with local devil legends and a themed hotel.

Hereward the Wake was a Lincolnshire-born noble who led stubborn resistance to the Norman conquest from the Fens, especially around Ely. His real exploits blurred with legend, turning him into a folk hero sometimes likened to Robin Hood

A village pub called the Sebastopol Inn supposedly got its name after a Crimean War soldier drank there, drowned on his way home, and the inquest hastily needed a name for the unnamed tavern—choosing “Sebastopol” in honour of the siege. Though unverified, census records show the inn adopted the name soon after the war, giving the legend a glimmer of plausibility
